turns.speaker: ARTIE
turns.text: Wait a minute.  This is the woman I love.  What's going on? Who was loaded?

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Don't worry.  She's just a fan for my literary output.

turns.speaker: ARTIE
turns.text: Walking out on the mob.  What's the big idea?

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: I'm sorry about New Year's. Would you believe me if I said I had to be with a sick friend?

turns.speaker: ARTIE
turns.text: Someone in the formal set, no doubt, with a ten-carat kidney stone.

turns.speaker: ARTIE
turns.text: The accent! I've got it: this guy is in the pay of a foreign government. Get those studs.  Get those cuff-links.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: I've got to run along.  Thanks any- way for your interest in my career.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Hello, Mr. Sheldrake.  On that Bases Loaded.  I covered it with a 2-page synopsis.  But I wouldn't bother.

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: What's wrong with it?

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: It's from hunger.

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: Nothing for Ladd?

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Just a rehash of something that wasn't very good to begin with.

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: I'm sure you'll be glad to meet Mr. Gillis.  He wrote it.

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: This is Miss Kramer.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Schaefer.  Betty Schaefer.  And right now I wish I could crawl into a hole and pull it in after me.

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: Name dropper.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: I just think pictures should say a little something.

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: Carefull Those are dirty words! You sound like a bunch of New York critics.  Thank you, Miss Schaefer.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Goodbye, Mr. Gillis.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: If I could be of any help...

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: I'm sorry, Mr. Gillis, but I just don't think it's any good. I found it flat and banal.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Exactly what kind of material do you recommend?  James Joyce? Dostoosvsky?

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Perhaps the reason I hated Bases Loaded is that I knew your name. I'd always heard you had some talent.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: That was last year.  This year I'm trying to earn a living.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: So you take Plot 27-A, make it glossy, make it slick --

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Let me help you.  Betty Schaeter, Sheldrake's office.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Sure.  Bases Loaded.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Hurt feelings department.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: About that luggage.  Where's the phone?

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: You forgot this.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Thanks.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: I've been hoping to run into you.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: What for? To recover that knife you stuck in my back?

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: I felt a little guilty, so I got out some of your old stories.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Why, you sweet kid.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: There's one called....Window... something with a window.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Dark Windows.  How did you like it?

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: I didn't.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Except for about six pages. You've got a flashback there ...

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Is there someplace we can talk?

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: How about the Rainbow Room?

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Now if I got you correctly, there was a short stretch of my fiction you found worthy of notice.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: The flashback in the courtroom, when she tells about being a school teacher.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: I had a teacher like that once.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Maybe that's why it's good. It's true, it's moving.  Now why don't you use that character...

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Who wants true? Who wants moving?

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Drop that attitude.  Here's some- thing really worth while.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Want me to start right now? Maybe there's some paper around.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: I'm serious.  I've got a few ideas.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: I've got some ideas myself.  One of them being this is New Year's Eve.  How about living it up a little?

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: As for instance?

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Well....

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: We could make some paper boats and have a regatta.  Or should we just turn on the shower?

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: How about capturing the kitchen and barricading the door?

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Are you hungry?

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Hungry? After twelve years in the Burmese jungle.  I am starving, Lady Agatha -- starving for a white shoulder --

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Phillip, you're mad!

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: No, Phillip, no.  We must be strong.  You're still wearing the uniform of the Coldstream Guards!  Furthermore, you can have the phone now.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: O.K.  I find I'm terribly afraid of losing you.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: You won't.  I'll get us a refill of this awful stuff.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: You'll be waiting for me?

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: With a wildly beating heart.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Life can be beautiful!

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Hello, Artie.  Good evening, Miss Schaefer.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: You don't know how glad I am to see youl

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Stop it, Artie, will you?  Where have you been keeping your- self? I've got the most wonderful news for you.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: I haven't been keeping myself at all.  Not lately.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: I called your agent.  I called the Screen Writers Guild.  Finally your old apartment gave me some Crestview number.  There was always somebody with an accent growling at me.  You were not there.  You were not to be spoken to.  They never heard of you.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Is that so? What's the wonderful news?

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Sheldrake likes that angle about the teacher.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: What teacher?

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Dark Windows.  I got him all hopped up about it.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: You did?

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: He thinks it could be made into something.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Into what? A lampshade?

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Into something for Barbara Stan- wyck.  They have a commitment with Barbara Stanwyck.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: O.K.  Where's the cash?

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Where's the story? I bluffed it out with a few notions of my own. It's really just a springboard. It needs work.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: I was afraid of that.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: I've got twenty pages of notes. I've got a pretty good character for the man.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Sorry, Miss Schaefer, but I've given up writing on spec.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: I tell you this is half sold.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: As a matter of fact.  I've given up writing altogether.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: It's not your career -- it's mine. I kind of hoped to get in on this deal.  I don't want to be a reader all my life.  I want to write.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Sorry if I crossed you up.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: You sure have.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: So long.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Just so you don't think I'm a complete swine -- if there's anything in Dark Windows you can use, take it.  It's all yours.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Well, for heaven's sake!

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: I mean it.  It's no good to me anyway.  Help yourself.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Why should you do that?

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: If you get a hundred thousand for it, you buy me a box of chocolate creams.  If you get an Oscar, I get the left foot.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: You know, I'd take you up on that in a minute.  I'm just not good enough to do it all by myself.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: What about all those ideas you had?

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: See if they make sense.  To begin with, I think you should throw out all that psychological stuff -- exploring a killer's sick mind.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Psychopaths sell like hotcakes.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: This story is about teachers -- their threadbare lives, their struggles.  Here are people doing the most important job in the world, and they have to wprry about getting enough money to re-sole their shoes.  To me it can be as exciting as any chase, any gunplay.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Check.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Now I see her teaching day classes while he teaches night school.  The first time they meet ...

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Look, if you don't mind, I haven't got time to listen to the whole plot ...

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: I'll make it short.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Sorry.  It's your baby now.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: I'm not good enough to write it alone.  We'll have to do it together.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: I'm all tied up.  I can't.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Couldn't we work in the evenings? Six o'clock in the morning? This next month I'm completely at your disposal.  Artie is out of town.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: What has Artie to do with it.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: We're engaged.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Good for you.  You've got yourself the best guy in town.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: I think so.  They're on location in Arizona, shooting a Western. I'm free every evening, every week- end.  If you want, we could work at your place.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: It's just impossible.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Nobody can be that busy.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Look, Betty, It can't be done. It's out.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: You're tough, all right.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: You're on your own.  Stop being chicken-hearted and write that story.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Honest to goodness, I hate you.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: And don't make it too dreary.  How about this for a situation: she teaches daytimes.  He teaches at night.  Right?  They don't even know each other, but they share the same room.  It's cheaper that way.  As a matter of fact, they sleep in the same bed -- in shifts, of oourse.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Are you kidding? Because I think it's good.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: So do I.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Came  on back.  Let me show you where it fits in.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Oh, you --

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: And here's a title: AN APPLE FOR THE TEACHER.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Good.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: What's good about it?  I miss him something fierce.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: I mean this is good dialogue along in here.  It'll play.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: It will?

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Sure.  Especially with lots of music underneath, drowning it out.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Don't you sometimes hate yourself?

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Constantly.  No, in all serious- ness, it's really good.  It's fun writing again.  I'm happy here, honest I am.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Who's Norma?

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Who's who?

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: I'm sorry.  I don't usually read private cigarette cases.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Oh, that.  It's from a friend of mine.  A middle-aged lady, very foolish and very generous.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: I'll say.  This is solid gold.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: I gave her some advice on an idiotic script.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: It's that old familiar story, you help a timid little soul across a crowded street.  She turns out to be a multimillionaire and leaves you all her money.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: That's the trouble with you readers.  You know all the plots. Now suppose you proof-read page ten while the water boils.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Look at this street.  All card- board, all hollow, all phoney. All done with mirrors.  I like it better than any street in the world.  Maybe because I used to play here when I was a kid.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: What were you -- a child actress?

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: I was born just two blocks from this studio.  Right on Lemon Grove Avenue.  Father was head elec- trician here till he died.  Mother still works in Wardrobe.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Second generation, huh?

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Third.  Grandma did stunt work for Pearl White.  I come from a picture family.  Naturally they took it for granted I was to become a great star.  So I had ten years of dramatic lessons, diction, dancing. Then the studio made a test.  Well, they didn't like my nose -- it slanted this way a little.  I went to a doctor and had it fixed.  They made more tests, and they were crazy about my nose -- only they didn't like my acting.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Nice job.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Should be.  It cost three hundred dollars.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Saddest thing I ever heard.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Not at all.  It taught me a little sense.  I got me a job in the mail room, worked up to the Stenographic. Now I'm a reader...

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Come clean, Betty.  At night you weep for those lost closeups, those gala openings...

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Not once.  What's wrong with being on the other side of the cameras? It's really more fun.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Three cheers for Betty Schaefer! I will now kiss that nose of yours.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: If you please.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: May I say you smell real special.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: It must be my new shampoo.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: That's no shampoo.  It'smore like a pile of freehly laundred hand- kerchiefs, like a brand new auto- mobile.  How old are you anyway?

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Twenty-two.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: That's it -- there's nothing like being twenty-two.  Now may I suggest that if we're ever to finish this story you keep at least two feet away from me ...  Now back to the typewriter.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Hey, what's the matter... Betty, wake up!  Why are you staring at me like that?

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Was I?  I'm sorry.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: What's wrong with you tonight? What is it, Betty?

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Something came up.  I don't want to talk about it.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Why not?

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: I just don't.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: What is it you've heard.  Come on, let's have it.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Betty, there's no use running out on it.  Let's face it, what- ever it is.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: It's nothing.  I got a telegram from Artie.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: From Artie.  What's wrong?

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: He wants me to come on to Arizona. He says it only oosts two dollars to get married there.  It would kind of save us a honeymoon.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Why don't you? We can finish the script by Thursday.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Stop crying.  You're getting married.  That's what you've always wanted.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: I don't want it now.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Why not? Don't you love Artie?

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Of course I love him.  I always will.  I'm just not in love with him any more.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: What happened?

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: You did.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Hello, Betty.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: I don't know why I'm so scared, Joe.  Is it something awful?

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Come on in, Betty,

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Ever been in one of these old Hollywood palazzos? That's from when they were making eighteen thou- sand a week, and no taxes.  Careful of these tiles, they're slippery. Valentino used to dance here.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: This is where you live?

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: You bet.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Whose house is it?

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Hers.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Whose?

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Just look around.  There's a lot of her spread about.  If you don't remember the face, you must have heard the name of Norma Desmond.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: That was Norma Desmond on the phone?

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Want something to drink?  There's always champagne on ice, and plenty of caviar.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Why did she call me?

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Jealous.  Ever see so much junk? She had the ceiling brought from Portugal.  Look at this.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Her own movie theatre.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: I didn't come here to see a house. What about Norma Desmond?

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: I'm trying to tell you.  This is an enormous place.  Eight master bedrooms.  A sunken tub in every bathroom.  There's a bowling alley in the cellar.  It's lonely here, so she got herself a companion. A very simple set-up: An older woman who is well-to-do.  A younger man who is not doing too well ... Can you figure it out yourself?

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: All right.  I'll give you a few more clues.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: No, no! I haven't heard any of this.  I never got those telephone calls.  I've never been in this house ... Get your things together. Let's get out of here.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: All my things? All the eighteen suits, all the custom-made shoes and the eighteen dozen shirts, and the cuff-links and the platinum key- chains, and the cigarette cases?

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Come on, Joe.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Come on where? Back to a one-room apartment that I can't pay for? Back to a story that may sell and very possibly will not?

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: If you love me, Joe.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Look, sweetie -- be practical. l've got a good thing here. A long-term contract with no options. I like it that way.  Maybe it's not very admirable.  Well, you and Artie can be admirable.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Joe, I can't look at you any more.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Nobody asked you to.

turns.speaker: DE MILLE
turns.text: Hello, young fellow.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: Hello, Mr. deMille.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: Last time I saw you was someplace very gay.  I remember waving to you. I was dancing on a table.

turns.speaker: DE MILLE
turns.text: Lots of people were.  Lindbergh had just landed in Paris.  Come on in.

turns.speaker: DE MILLE
turns.text: Norma, I want to apologize for not calling you.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: You'd better.  I'm very angry.

turns.speaker: DE MILLE
turns.text: I'm pretty busy, as you can see...

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: That's no excuse.  You read the script, didn't you?

turns.speaker: DE MILLE
turns.text: Yes, I did.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: Then you could have picked up the phone yourself instead of leaving it to one of your assistants.

turns.speaker: DE MILLE
turns.text: What assistant?

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: Don't play innocent.  Somebody named Gordon Cole.

turns.speaker: DE MILLE
turns.text: Gordon Cole?

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: And if you hadn't been pretty darned interested in that script, he wouldn't have tried to get me on the phone ten times.

turns.speaker: DE MILLE
turns.text: Gordon Cole... Look, Norma, I'm in the middle of a rehearsal.  Make yourself comfortable.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: Did you see them? Did you see how they came?

turns.speaker: DE MILLE
turns.text: You know, crazy things happen in this business.  I hope you haven't lost your sense of humor ...

turns.speaker: DE MILLE
turns.text: Goodbye, young fellow.  We'll see what we can do.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: I'm not worried.  Everything will be fine.  The old team together. Nothing can stop us.

turns.speaker: DEMILLE
turns.text: What's the matter, Norma?

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: Nothing.  I just didn't realize what it would be like to come back to the old studio.  I had no idea how I'd missed it.

turns.speaker: DEMILLE
turns.text: We've missed you too, dear.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: We'll be working again, won't we, Chief? We'll make our greatest picture.

turns.speaker: DEMILLE
turns.text: That's what I want to talk to you about.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: It's a good script, isn't it?

turns.speaker: DEMILLE
turns.text: It's got a lot of good things.  Of course, it would be an expensive picture...

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: I don't care about the money. I just want to work again.  You don't know what it means to know that you want me.

turns.speaker: DEMILLE
turns.text: Nothing would thrill me more -- if it were possible.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: But remember, darling -- I don't work before ten in the morning, and never after 4:30 in the afternoon.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: I wouldn't know.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: I don't care anyway.  I want the coffin to be white.  And I want it specially lined with satin. White, or deep pink.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: How much will it be?  I warn you - don't give me a fancy price just because I'm rich.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Lady.  you've got the wrong man.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: I had some trouble with my car. Flat tire.  I pulled into your garage till I could get a spare. I thought this was an empty house.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: It is not.  Get out.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: I'm sorry, and I'm sorry you lost your friend, and I don't think red is the right color.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: Get out.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Sure.  Wait a minute -- haven't I seen you -- ?

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: Or shall I call my servant?

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: I know your face.  You're Norma Desmond.  You used to be in pictures.  You used to be big.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: I am big.  It's the pictures that got small.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: I knew there was something wrong with them.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: They're dead.  They're finished. There was a time when this busi- ness had the eyes of the whole wide world.  But that wasn't good enough.  Oh, nol They wanted the ears of the world, too.  So they opened their big mouths, and out came talk, talk, talk...

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: That's where the popcorn business comes in.  You buy yourself a bag and plug up your ears.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: Look at them in the front offices -- the master minds! They took the idols and smashed them.  The Fairbankses and the Chaplins and the Gilberts and the Valentinos. And who have they got now?  Some nobodies -- a lot of pale little frogs croaking pish-poshl

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Don't get sore at me.  I'm not an executive.  I'm just a writer.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: You are! Writing words, words! You've made a rope of words and strangled this businessl But there is a microphone right there to catch the last gurgles, and Technicolor to photograph the red, swollen tongue!

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Ssh! You'll wake up that monkey.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: Get out!

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: Just a minute, you!

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Yeah?

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: You're a writer, you said.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: Are you or aren't you?

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: I think that's what it says on my driver's license.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: And you have written pictures, haven't you?

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Sure have.  The last one I wrote was about cattle rustlers. Before they were through with it, the whole thing played on a torpedo boat.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: The wind gets in that blasted pipe organ.  I ought to have it taken out.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Or teach it a better tune.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: How long is a movie script these days?  I mean, how many pages?

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Depends on what it is -- a Donald Duck or Joan or Arc.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: This is to be a very important picture.  I have written it myself.  Took me years.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Looks like enough for six impor- tant pictures.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: It's the story or Salome.  I think I'll have DeMille direct it.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Uh-huh.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: We've made a lot of pictures together.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: And you'll play Salome?

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: Who else ?

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Only asking.  I did't know you were planning a comeback.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: I hate that word.  It is a return. A return to the millions of people who have never forgiven me for deserting the screen.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Fair enough.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: Salome -- what a woman! What a part! The Princess in love with a Holy man.  She dances the Dance of the Seven Veils.  He rejects her, so she demands his head on a golden tray, kissing his cold, dead lips.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: They'll love it in Pomona.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: They will love it every place.  Read it.  Read the scene just before she has him killed!

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Right now?  Never let another writer read your stuff.  He may steal it.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: I am not afraid.  Read it!

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: Well?

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: This is fascinating.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: Of course it is.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Maybe it's a little long and maybe there are some repetitions... but you're not a professional writer.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: I wrote that with my heart.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Sure you did.  That's what makes it great.  What it needs is a little more dialogue.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: What for?  I can say anything I want with my eyes.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: It certainly could use a pair of shears and a blue pencil.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: I will not have it butchered.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Of course not.  But it ought to be organized.  Just an editing job.  You can find somebody.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: Who?  I'd have to have somebody I can trust.  When were you born -- I mean, what sign of the zodiac?

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: What month?

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: December twenty-first.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: Sagittarius.  I like Sagittarians. You can trust them.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: I want you to do this work.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Me?  I'm busy.  Just finished one script.  I'm due on another assignment.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: I don't care.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: You know, I'm pretty expensive. I get five hundred a week.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: I wouldn't worry about money. I'll make it worth your while.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Maybe I'd better take the rest of the script home and read it -

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: Oh no.  I couldn't let it out of my house.  You'll have to finish it here.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: It's getting kind of late --

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: Are you married, Mr.  -- ?

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: The name is Gillis.  I'm single.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: Where do you live?

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Hollywood.  The Alto Nido Apart- ments.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: There's something wrong with your car, you said.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: There sure is.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: You can stay here.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: I'll come early tomorrow.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: I don't know why you should be so upset.  Stop that playing, Max.  It seemed like a good idea -- if we are to work together.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Look, I'm supposed to fix up your script.  There's nothing in the deal about my staying here.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: You'll like it here.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Thanks for the invitation, but I have my own apartment.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: You can't work in an apartment where you owe three months' rent.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: I'll take care of that.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: It's all taken care of.  It's all paid for.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: I'm used to paying my own bills.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: You proud boy, why didn't you tell me you were having difficulties.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Okay.  We'll deduct it from my salary.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: Now, now, don't let's be small about such matters.  We won't keep books.  Go on, unpack Mr. Gillis' things.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Unpack nothing.  I didn't say I was staying.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: Suppose you make up your mind. Do you want this job or don't you?

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: What's that?

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Just a scene I cut out.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: What scene?

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: The one where you go to the slave market.  You can cut right to the scene where John the Baptist -

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: Cut away from me?

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Honestly, it's a little old hat. They don't want that any more.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: They don't?  Then why do they still write me fan letters every day. Why do they beg me for my photo- graphs?  Because they want to see me, me, me!  Norma Desmond.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: I want to talk to you for a minute.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: Not now, my dear.  I'm playing three no trump.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: They've come for my car.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: Please.  Now I've forgotten how many spades are out.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: I need some money right now.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: Can't you wait till I'm dummy?

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: Now what is it?  Where's the fire?

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: I've lost my car.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: Oh...and I thought it was a matter of life and death.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: It is to me.  That's why I came to this house.  That's why I took this job -- ghost writing!

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: Now you're being silly.  We don't need two cars.  We have a car.  And not one of thuse cheap new things made of chromium and spit.  An Isotta-Fraschini.  Have you ever heard of Isotta-Fraschinis?  All hand-made.  Cost me twenty-eight thousand dollars.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: That's a dreadful shirt you're wearing.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: What's wrong with It?

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: Nothing, if you work in a fill- ing station.  And I'm getting rather bored with that sport jacket, and those same baggy pants.  Max, what's a good men's shop in town?  The very best... Well, go there !

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: I don't need any clothes, and I certainly don't want you buy- ing them for --

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: Why begrudge me a little fun? I just want you to look nice, my stray little boy.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: How about some evening clothes?

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: I don't need a tuxedo.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: Of course you do.  A tuxedo and tails.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Tails.  That's ridiculous.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: You'll need them for parties. You'll need them for New Year's Eve.  Where are your evening clothes?

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: Joe,  you look absolutely divine.  Turn around!

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: Come on!

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: All padding.  Don't let it fool you.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: Come here!

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: You know, to me dressing up was always just putting on my dark blue suit.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: I don't like those studs they've sent.  I want you to have pearls. Nice big pearls.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Now, I'm not going to wear ear- rings, I can tell you that.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: Cute.  Let's have some drinks.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Shouldn't we wait for the others?

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: Careful, it's slippery.  I had it waxed.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Not on the same floor with Valentino!

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: Just follow me.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: Don't bend back like that.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: It's those feathers.  They tickle.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: It's a quarter past ten.  What time are they supposed to get here?

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: Who?

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: The other guests?

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: There are no other guests.  We don't want to share this night with other people.  This is for you and me.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: I understand some rich guy bought up all the tickets for a perfor- mance at the Metropolitan and sat there listening to La Traviata, all by himself.  He was afraid of catching cold.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: Hold me tighter.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Come midnight, how about blind- folding the orchestra and smash- ing champagne glasses on Max's head?

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: You think this is all very funny.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: A little.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: Is it funny that I'm in love with you?

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: What's that?

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: I'm in love with you.  Don't you know that? I've been in love with you all along.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: What are the notes?

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: "Mad about the boy."

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Norma, I can't take it.  You've bought me enough.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: Shut up.  I'm rich.  I'm richer than all this new Hollywood trash. I've got a million dollars.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Keep it.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: I own three blocks downtown. I have oil in Bakersfield -- pumping, pumping, pumping. What's it for but to buy us anything we want.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Cut out that us business.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: What's the matter with you?

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: What right do you have to take me for granted?

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: What right? Do you want me to tell you?

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Has it ever occurred that I may have a life of my own? That there may be some girl I'm crazy about?

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: Who? Some car hop, or a dress extra?

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Why not? What I'm trying to say is that I'm all wrong for you. You want a Valentino -- somebody with polo ponies -- a big shot --

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: What you're trying to say is that you don't want me to love you.  Is that it?

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: Go away.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: What kind of a silly thing was that to do?

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: To fall in love with you -- that was the idiotic thing.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: It sure would have made attractive headlines: Great Star Kills Her- self for Unknown Writer.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: Great stars have great pride.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: Go away.  Go to that girl of yours.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Look, I was making that up because I thought the whole thing was a mistake.  I didn't want to hurt you. You've been good to me.  You're the only person in this stinking town that has been good to me.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: Why don't you just say thank you and go, go, go --

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Not until you promise to act like a sensible human being.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: I'll do it again, I'll do it again, I'll do it again!

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: You're really going to send it to De Mille?

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: This is the right day.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Did she read the script?

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: DeMille is Leo.  I'm Scorpio. Mars has been transmitting Jupiter for weeks.  Today is the day of greatest conjuction. Now turn around.  Let me dry you.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: I hope you realize, Norma, that scripts don't sell on astrologers' charts.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: I'm not just selling the script. I'm selling me.  DeMille always said I was his greatest star.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: When did he say it, Norma?

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: So he said it quite a few years ago.  So what?  I never looked better in my life.  Do you know why?  Because I've never been as happy in my life.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Have one of mine.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: They're awful.  They make me cough.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Pull up at the drugstore, will you, Max.  I'll get you some.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: You're a darling.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: What on earth, darling? It took you hours.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: I ran into some people I knew.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: Where are my cigarettes?

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Where are your...?

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: I can still see myself in the line: Bebe Daniels, Marie Prevost, Mabel Normand ... Mabel was always stepping on my feet ...What's the matter with you, darling?  Why are you so glum?

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Nothing is the matter.  I'm having a great time.  Show me some more.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: All right.  Give me this.  I need it for a moustache.  Now close your eyes.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: How do you like that? We've made twelve pictures together. His greatest successes.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Maybe deMille is shooting.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: I know that trick! He wants to belittle me.  He's trying to get my price down.  I've waited twenty years for this call.  Now Mr. deMille can wait till I'm good and ready.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: Don't you want to come along, darling?

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: I don't think so.  It's your script.  It's your show. Good luck.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: Thank you, darling.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: How did it go?

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: It couldn't have gone better. It's practically set.  Of course, he has to finish this picture first, but mine will be his next.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: He must be quite a guy.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: He'a a shrewd old fox.  He can smell box office.  Only I'm going to outfox him a litt1e.  This isn't going to be C. B. deMille's Salome. It's going to be Norma Desmond's Salome, a Norma Desmond Production, starring Norma Desmond...Home, Max.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: Don't turn around.  Keep your eyes on the book.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Yes, Norma.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: I just came to say good night. I don't want you to see me -- I'm not very attractive.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Good night.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: I've lost half a pound since Tuesday.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Good.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: I was a little worried about the line of my throat.  This woman has done wonders with it.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Good.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: You'd better get to bed yourself.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: I think I'll read a little.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: You went out last night, didn't you, Joe?

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Why do you say that?

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: I just happen to know it.  I had a nightmare and I screamed for you.  You weren't here.  Where were you?

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: I went for a walk.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: No you didn't.  You took the car.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: All right, I drove to the beach. Norma, you don't want me to feel I'm locked up in this house?

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: Of course not, Joe.  It's just that I don't want to be left alone. Not now, while I'm under this terrible strain.  My nerves are being torn apart.  All I ask is for you to be a little patient and a little kind.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: I haven't done anything, Norma.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: Of course you haven't.  I wouldn't let you.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: What are you doing, Joe?  What are you doing?  You're not leaving me?

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Yes, I am, Norma.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: No, you're not.  Max! Max!

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Max is a good idea.  He can help with my luggage.  Thanks for letting me wear the handsome wardrobe.  And thanks for the use of all the trinkets.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: The rest of the jewelry is in the top drawer.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: It's yours, Joe.  I gave it to you.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: And I'd take it in a second, Norma -- only it's a little too dressy for sitting behind the copy desk in Dayton, Ohio.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: These are nothing.  You can have anything you want if you'll only stay.  What is it you want -- money?

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Norma, you'd be throwing it away. I don't qualify for the job, not any more.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: You can't do this!  Max!  Max! ... I can't face life without you, and I'm not afraid to die, you know.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: That's between you and yourself, Norma.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: You think I made that up about the gun...

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: See, you didn't believe me!.. Now I suppose you don't think I have the courage!

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Oh.  sure -- if it would make a good scene.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: You don't care.  do you?  But hundreds of thousands of people will carel

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Wake up, Norma.  You'd be killing yourself to an empty house.  The audience left twenty years ago. Now face it.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: That's a lie!  They still want me!

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: No, they don't.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: What about the studio? What about De Mille?

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: He was trying to spare your feelings. The studio wanted to rent your car.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: Wanted what?

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: De Mille didn't have the heart to tell you.  None of us has had the heart.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: That's a lie!  They want me, they want me!  I get letters every day!

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: You tell her, Max.  Come on, do her that favor.  Tell her there isn't going to be any picture -- there aren't any fan letters, except the ones you write yourself.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: That isn't true! Max?

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: You heard him.  I'm a star!

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Norma, grow up.  You're a woman of fifty.  There's nothing tragic about being fifty - not unless you try to be twenty-five.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: I'm the greatest star of them all.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Goodbye.  Norma.

turns.speaker: NORMA
turns.text: No one leaves a star.  That makes one a star.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: I just put my car in the garage. I had a blow-out.  I thought --

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: Go on in.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Look, maybe I'd better take my car --

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: Wipe your feet!

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: You are not dressed properly.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Dressed for what?

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Suppose you listen just for a minute -

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: Madame is waiting.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: For me?  Okay.

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: I made your bed this afternoon.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Thanks.  How did you know I was going to stay, this afternoon?

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: This room has not been used for a long time.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: It will never make house Beautiful. I guess it's O.K. for one night.

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: There is the bathroom.  I put in soap and a toothbrush.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Thanks.  Say, she's quite a character, that Norma Desmond.

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: She was the greatest.  You wouldn't know.  You are too young.  In one week she got seventeen thousand fan letters.  Men would bribe her mani- curist to get clippings from her fingernails.  There was a Maharajah who came all the way from Hyderabad to get one of her stockings.  Later, he strangled himself with it.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: I sure turned into an interesting driveway.

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: You did, sir. GILLIS' VOICE He goes out.  Gillis     I pegged him as slightly looks after him, hangs   cuckoo, too.  A stroke maybe. his coat over a chair,   Come to think of it, the walks over to the win-   whole place seemed to have dow, pulls down the      been stricken with a kind of rickety Venetian blind.  creeping paralysis, out of As he does so, he looks  beat with the rest of the down at:                 world, crumbling apart in slow motion ...

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: I'm talking to you.  My clothes and things are up in the room.

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: Naturally.  I brought them myself.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Is that so!

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: Why are you so upset?  Is there anything missing?

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Who said you could?  Who asked you to?

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: Some men are here.  They asked for you.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: I'm not here.

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: That's what I told them.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Good.

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: They found your car in the garage.  They are going to tow it away.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Whose room was this?

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: It was the room of the husband. Or of the husbands, I should say. Madame has been married three times.

turns.speaker: GILLIS
turns.text: Hey, what's this with the door? There isn't any lock.

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: There are no locks anywhere in this house.
